title: Where did Medieval English Kings stay when they toured their kingdom? How did he decide which noble would house them? - Quora

response.answer_text: Kings typically owned many castles, manors, and lodges located in and around forests. Their seneschal would advice the stewards and castellans when to expect the royal household & what their needs would be. The royal seneschal would also notify the major nobles that the King would be visiting their castle or manor. Also, if the weather turned very nasty, the royal party might stay at a major monastery or convent even spreading his party out among several monasteries and convents in a certain area. The King might also stay in or near a city or town, especially if there was a major horse market or seasonal fair being conducted in the vicinity. It was important for the King's seneschal to make these arrangements not only because of the need for there to be adequate food and drink but also to ensure that hunts and other activities be arranged.

For several centuries the kings of England had no fixed abode, let alone in London, and the whole court moved from place to place, usually staying at the grandest house in each county for a month or two. Some rich noblemen built whole palaces hoping the king would come and stay, because making a good impression on the king would set them up for life. Some of these grand houses survive, and their tour guides can tell you whether the king ever arrived or not.

Medieval kings owned many residences of their own and would stay there rather than the homes of nobles. Dover Castle for example, Clarendon in Wiltshire, Guildford, Woodstock, etc. They moved around a good deal. They might stay with a noble perhaps if they were visiting an era where they didn’t have a Castle or palace of their own, but they had a lot of residences.

Mostly they stayed at castles or manors of Dukes or knights near to the route the Royal party was travelling, and who owed their allegience to the monarch. Whoever they stayed with had to organise accomodation, food and provisions for hundreds of people and animals in the monarch entourage, all at their own expense.

England was dotted with royal castles and manors, so the kings mostly stayed in one of their own houses. Staying with a noble could be either a sign of favour or a punishment - depending on how much of the cost the king bore. The royal household was quite large but the king could bring his own provisions or contribute from his estates.

usually at the homes/castles of the nobility. They would be chosen by rank and proximity. it was an honor to so serve the king.If no nobility was close enough the king could commandeer an inn or home of a local. Paul Ross

A part of feudalism was that a king would tour all the nobles in his kingdom every year to collect tribute. During his tour, every noble he came to was expected to house and feed him and his household.

Hi thanks for asking. Usually it was with relatives. They are were notorious for keeping wealth and power in the family. If not then Abbies or Monasteries where the Bishops and Archbishops were trusted. Failing that close friends who were in debt or seeking favors from the Court. Kinda like today with the rich and famous. Hope this helps. Cheers.
